course.subject: GBUS
course.name: From Zero to Exit – Journey of A Start-up
course.description: This course is designed for students who are interested in starting a business or working for an entrepreneurial company. Students are expected to understand the opportunities and challenges of a start-up journey, from coming up with their own start up idea to incepting the idea, pitching for funding and to growing their own start-up. At the end of the course, they will be equipped with the skills and knowledge necessary to kick start their business as an entrepreneur.

reviews.author: VLi
reviews.title: "A for effort"
reviews.comment_content:
The content has minor tweaks every semester, during my time the syllabus was as described in the following:

You will be led through the journey of establishing a start-up with 10 classroom sessions, each providing an overview of a key aspect of the start-up.

First to examine the macro and the micro of the start-up ecosystems through 2 sessions:

• Current landscape, challenges, and opportunities of technology start up in Hong Kong
• Essence of the start-up journey – facing the realities

The next 8 sessions will get down to the work, examining the various operational aspects of your start-up venture:
• Product Design: Managing your creations – from drawing board to the board room
• Sales Pitch: Your first success story – selling to strategic customers
• Partnering Strategy: Scaling up your start-up – building a channel business model
• Talent Management: Building a successful team – from garage hobbyist to becoming a CEO
• Branding & Position: Building a brand for your start-up
• Legal: Protecting your business – legal must-knows
• Investor Pitch: Are you ready to pitch - your first business plan that matters
• Regional Expansion: Going beyond HK – the regional strategy
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Koc likes to do 2 things:
1. interact with students, and
2. leverage on his network, getting guest speakers to share the latest industry insights in the start-up scene.

As an Adjunct Professor, he has extensive industry experience and currently works with a lot of start-ups, so that enhances the learning experience for those who are interested in the HK start-up scene.

About your instructor:
https://www.linkedin.com/in/joseph-koc-aa48332/
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is very much based on how much you care and how much thought you put into each of his assignments.

If you happen to disagree with Professor Koc's assignment grading results, it is recommended that you reach out to him in person and talk it out.

Professor Koc values reasoning and logic a little more than his ego; he will give you his personal number so you can reach him more conveniently about things like this. There were many students that were able to successfully appeal for their assignment grades (not the final SIS one, once that's out it's too late), as they were willing to put in the time and effort to communicate their logic behind their work.

So really, as long as you show up, speak up, work hard and be willing to learn, your efforts will be compensated.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is reasonable as there's nothing much to prep for every class except for questions to ask about the topic.

NO QUIZ, NO EXAM.

You will write 2 essays and do a final group project designing a business development strategy for a real start-up. The majority of the workload is really discussing your deliverables and making sure you are incorporating your learnings and moving towards a viable direction with the professor.

reviews.author: demelza
reviews.comment_content: interesting if you are interested in startups. it teaches you about the essentials of startup industry with cases.
reviews.comment_teaching: the first half of the class is joseph introducing the concepts and the second half is guest speaker session.
reviews.comment_grading: transparent but not sure of its objectivity. speaking up is very important. even if you attend, that does not mean you get the participation mark.
reviews.comment_workload: not too heavy as there are one team project and one writing. but pray for a good teammate. it is randomly assigned. good thing is that there is no quiz and exam but don't choose this course if this is the only reason. the team project can be demanding.

reviews.author: Fran51
reviews.comment_content: Cover whole process and from both perspective of entrepreneur and corporate looking to collaborate with a startup. second half of lectures contain guest speakers who provide great insight.
reviews.comment_teaching: mostly presentation and discussion based. very interactive.
reviews.comment_grading: grading felt fair. The primary focus is on presentation and report. It’s quite hard to understand what he wants from the presentation. As long as what you are saying is backed by evidence there should not be too many issues. Make sure to ask the professor often if you have any questions.
reviews.comment_workload: the workload can get quite high towards the end of semester as you work on both the presentation and report.
